text:
ai What is a cell?
   ii name three scientists that are associated with the discovery of the cell.
   b. make a diagram, 6cm to 8cm long of a plant cell and label only the organelle responsible for cell production
       name one blood cell in humans that does not have the oraganelle labelled in [b]i.
      iii What is the biological implication of the cell named in  (b)(i) not possessing the organelle responsible for
        cell reproduction?
          (c) List six organelles found in a plant celI.
correct_answer:
(a)(i) Cell is the basic/smallest structural/building block; and functional unit; of life.
(ii) Scientists that are associated with the discovery of the cell.
ii Robert Hooke
ii Matthias Schleiden
iii Theodor Schwann
iv Rudolf Virchow
v Felix Dujardin(b) Diagram of a plant cell
ii Red blood cell/erythrocyte art[.iii ]iIt has a short life span ii Unable to reproduce more oxygen iii Gives room for carriage of more oxygen
[c] i  Nucleus  ii Chloroplas  iii Vacuole  iv Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum  v Smooth  Endopolasmic Reticulum  vi Lysosome  viii golgi body ix mithochondrion
explanation:
(a)(i) Cell is the basic/smallest structural/building block; and functional unit; of life.
(ii) Scientists that are associated with the discovery of the cell.
ii Robert Hooke
ii Matthias Schleiden
iii Theodor Schwann
iv Rudolf Virchow
v Felix Dujardin(b) Diagram of a plant cell
ii Red blood cell/erythrocyte art[.iii ]iIt has a short life span ii Unable to reproduce more oxygen iii Gives room for carriage of more oxygen
[c] i  Nucleus  ii Chloroplas  iii Vacuole  iv Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum  v Smooth  Endopolasmic Reticulum  vi Lysosome  viii golgi body ix mithochondrion

[b] [!] state three differences  between the definition of a herbivore and a carnivore

            [c] what are milk teeth?
b[i] State three differences between the definition of a herbivore and a carnivore
correct_answer: herbivorecarnivorepresence of diastemaabsence of diastemaabsence of caninepresence of canineabsence of carnassial teethpresence of carnassial teethridged molarcusped molar

text: b[ii]state four differences between the definition of a human and a goat
correct_answer:
[c} Human and goat
HumanGoatabsence of diastemapresence of diastemapresence of canineabsence of caninepresence of incisorabsence of dental padpresence of eight premolarpresence of twelve premolarsequal number of incisors in upper and lower jawpresence of incisors in upper and lower jaw
explanation:
[c} Human and goat
HumanGoatabsence of diastemapresence of diastemapresence of canineabsence of caninepresence of incisorabsence of dental padpresence of eight premolarpresence of twelve premolarsequal number of incisors in upper and lower jawpresence of incisors in upper and lower jaw

correct_answer:
i Are the first set of teeth grown by the infants of a human.
ii made up of inscisors,canines,and molars
iii premolars are absent.
iv the dental formulas is I2/2C1/1M2/2orI2/2C1/1P0/0M2/2
v they are also known as primary/temporal/decidious teeth/they are shed and replaced by permanent teeth.
explanation:
i Are the first set of teeth grown by the infants of a human.
ii made up of inscisors,canines,and molars
iii premolars are absent.
iv the dental formulas is I2/2C1/1M2/2orI2/2C1/1P0/0M2/2
v they are also known as primary/temporal/decidious teeth/they are shed and replaced by permanent teeth.

text:
(a)(i) What is an ecological niche?
 (i) State five roles played by a mango tree in its ecological niche.
(b)i) State two reasons why ecologists use sampling techniques in population studies.
(i) State four examples of sampling techniques used in population studies.
(c)Name four types of fingerprints in humans.
(d)) Name the plant used by Gregor Mendel in his experiment.
(ii) State two reasons why the plant named in 3(d) was used.
correct_answer:
a [i]Ecological nichewhere and organism lives and the role it plays in an ecosystem/community.[ii] Rolesof a mango tree in its ecological niche
i. absorbs water/mineral salts from the soil organism normally lives; and theii.absorbs sunlight for photosynthesisii.provides shelter for animals/other plantsIV.acts as support for creepersV. produces fruits/food/serves as foodVi. serves as fuel source for animals vii. covers the ground with dead leaves that enrich the soilb[ i] Counting individuals could be impossible/difficult in fast moving animals
ii. Counting individuals could be tedious ii. Counting individuals could be time consuming/use of technique saves time
iv. The terrian/habitat could be difficult to reach
[ii] i. Quadrat method     ii Random sampling method
ii.Sweep net method   iv cluster sampling
V. Pitfall trap method    vi. Line transect methodVili.Light trap method    ix. Stratified samplingX. Tullgren funnel method  xi. Convenience sampling
xii systematic sampling method
[c]i .Arch/tented arch ii compound
iii loops/double/central pocket/ulna radial loop
iv.whorls/accident/plain whorl
[d]i Pea plant/Garden pea plant/Pisum sativum.
ii a it is self-pollinated/flowers are bisexual
b has short life cycle
c produces many offspring in one cross
d presence of distinct physical characters that are easily recognisable.
b.Has a short life cycle
c.produces many offspring in one cross
d.presence of distinct physical characters that are easily recognisable
explanation:
a [i]Ecological nichewhere and organism lives and the role it plays in an ecosystem/community.[ii] Rolesof a mango tree in its ecological niche
i. absorbs water/mineral salts from the soil organism normally lives; and theii.absorbs sunlight for photosynthesisii.provides shelter for animals/other plantsIV.acts as support for creepersV. produces fruits/food/serves as foodVi. serves as fuel source for animals vii. covers the ground with dead leaves that enrich the soilb[ i] Counting individuals could be impossible/difficult in fast moving animals
ii. Counting individuals could be tedious ii. Counting individuals could be time consuming/use of technique saves time
iv. The terrian/habitat could be difficult to reach
[ii] i. Quadrat method     ii Random sampling method
ii.Sweep net method   iv cluster sampling
V. Pitfall trap method    vi. Line transect methodVili.Light trap method    ix. Stratified samplingX. Tullgren funnel method  xi. Convenience sampling
xii systematic sampling method
[c]i .Arch/tented arch ii compound
iii loops/double/central pocket/ulna radial loop
iv.whorls/accident/plain whorl
[d]i Pea plant/Garden pea plant/Pisum sativum.
ii a it is self-pollinated/flowers are bisexual
b has short life cycle
c produces many offspring in one cross
d presence of distinct physical characters that are easily recognisable.
b.Has a short life cycle
c.produces many offspring in one cross
d.presence of distinct physical characters that are easily recognisable

text:
(a) What are conversation laws?
(i) State three conservation laws
(b) State two reasons why animals are poached.
(i) Name five animals that are commonly poached.
(c) State four effects of excessive use of the forest.
(d) Explain briefly the following terms: i.blood transfusion ii.antigen
correct_answer:
(a)Conservation lawsAre set down rules/legislations with sanctions/ punishments for offenders/perpetrators; which regulate/protect the usage of natural resources/endangered species .
[ii] i. No unauthorised exploration of mineral/coal /gold/ petroleum/bauxite by individuals withoutpermit
ii. No killing of endangered species
ii. No use of poisonous chemicals/Gammalin 20 for fishing
iv. Observing closed season for hunting/fishing
V. No trading of body parts of endangered species
(b)i) a. For their unique body parts/tusks/skin/fin b. For sport/game
C. For money/trade/business
d. For food
e For trado-medicinal purposes.
i) a. Elephant b. Snake c. whale  d. Crocodile e. Lion  f. Zebra g. Deer
h. tiger i.rhinoceros  j.Shark   k.ape/gorilla  l. birds m. Pangolin/porcupine  n. leopard  o. hippopotamus
(c) i. There will be shortage of trees
ii. This will lead to shortage of timber over time for use in the furniture industry.
ii.The natural habitat of organisms will be destroyed
iv. Foreign exchange from timber export will reduce
v. Some useful herbs/medicinal plants will be destroyed
vi. Research sites will be destroyed
vii. There will be succession
viii.soils will be exposed to flooding/erosion
ix. carbon [iv] oxide emission leading to global warming
x. Desert encroachement/desertification
d iBlood transfusion
Is the process of administering blood from a healthy person/donor to an individual/patient recipient that requires/needs it.
iiAntigen
A substance/protein; found on the surface the red blood cells; that could stimulate/trigger the production of antibodies in the body/blood plasma.
explanation:
(a)Conservation lawsAre set down rules/legislations with sanctions/ punishments for offenders/perpetrators; which regulate/protect the usage of natural resources/endangered species .
[ii] i. No unauthorised exploration of mineral/coal /gold/ petroleum/bauxite by individuals withoutpermit
ii. No killing of endangered species
ii. No use of poisonous chemicals/Gammalin 20 for fishing
iv. Observing closed season for hunting/fishing
V. No trading of body parts of endangered species
(b)i) a. For their unique body parts/tusks/skin/fin b. For sport/game
C. For money/trade/business
d. For food
e For trado-medicinal purposes.
i) a. Elephant b. Snake c. whale  d. Crocodile e. Lion  f. Zebra g. Deer
h. tiger i.rhinoceros  j.Shark   k.ape/gorilla  l. birds m. Pangolin/porcupine  n. leopard  o. hippopotamus
(c) i. There will be shortage of trees
ii. This will lead to shortage of timber over time for use in the furniture industry.
ii.The natural habitat of organisms will be destroyed
iv. Foreign exchange from timber export will reduce
v. Some useful herbs/medicinal plants will be destroyed
vi. Research sites will be destroyed
vii. There will be succession
viii.soils will be exposed to flooding/erosion
ix. carbon [iv] oxide emission leading to global warming
x. Desert encroachement/desertification
d iBlood transfusion
Is the process of administering blood from a healthy person/donor to an individual/patient recipient that requires/needs it.
iiAntigen
A substance/protein; found on the surface the red blood cells; that could stimulate/trigger the production of antibodies in the body/blood plasma.

text:
5.(a) State three differences between the alimentary canals of earthworm and cockroach.
(i) State three similarities between the alimentary canals of earthworm and cockroach.
(b) The diagram below is an illustration of a biological cycle.
 Study it and answer questions 5(b)i) to 5(b)(iii)
 
[i]Name the biological cycle (i) Explain briefly three roles played by plants and animals in the cycle (ii) Name the process that occur in X, Y and Z.
 
 c. complete the table below.



organs associated with excretion in human
three diseases that affect the organ


 
 


 
 



(d)i) What is decay of organic matter
(i) Name two groups of organisms that cause decay of organic matter.
(i) State one other factor that causes decay.
(iv) Name the biological cycle that involves decay.
(e) Explain briefly the mode of nutrition in carnivorous plants.
correct_answer:
[a][i]
EarthwormcockroachSimple/sucking mouth partselaborate/biting/chewing mouth partsSimple/sucking mouth partsalimentary canal divided into fore gut, mid gut and hind gutdevelopedAbsence of mesenteric presence of mesentericcaecumpresence of mesentric caecumNo malpighian tubules attachedmalphigian tubules attached to canals
(i) SimilaritiesBoth
a. Mouth c. Gizzard e. Oesophagus
(b) Name of biological cycleWater
(ii) a. Plants and animals produce water as a product of respiration.
b. Plants give-off water through transpiration
c. Animals give off water perspiration/sweating/ urinating/excretion
d. Plants absorb water/animals drink water body metabolism.
(iii) x  -   Condensationy  -   Evaporationz  -   Evaporation
organs associated with ecretion in humanThree diseaes that affect the organkidneysnephritis,kidney,stones,diuresis,kidney cancer,polycystic kidney disease,diabetes,[inspidius]livercirrhosis,hepatitis,jaundice,dropsy,gall stones,diabetes,(mellitus),cancerskinscabies,ringworm,acne,eczema,boil,leprosy,cancer,dermatitis,cancer.lungsbronchitis,cancer,asthma,tuberculosis,pulmonary fibrosis.
d[i]DecayIs the breakdown of complex organic matter, into small compounds, so that their nutrient can be absorbed.(ii) Saprophytes/fungi, bacteria, detritivores/decomposers
(i) a. Temperature/Heat warmth
b.Osmotic pressurec.Amount of water
d.Amount of oxygen
iv) Carbon; Nitrogen
(e) a. They obtain nutrients from trapped insects and other small animalsb. The trapped insects are digested
c. And the amino acids are absorbed
d. Carnivorous plants grow on soils that are poor in nitrogen
e. Animal proteins supplement the nitrogenous compounds.

EarthwormcockroachSimple/sucking mouth partselaborate/biting/chewing mouth partsSimple/sucking mouth partsalimentary canal divided into fore gut, mid gut and hind gutdevelopedAbsence of mesenteric presence of mesentericcaecumpresence of mesentric caecumNo malpighian tubules attachedmalphigian tubules attached to canals
(i) SimilaritiesBoth
a. Mouth c. Gizzard e. Oesophagus
(b) Name of biological cycleWater
(ii) a. Plants and animals produce water as a product of respiration.
b. Plants give-off water through transpiration
c. Animals give off water perspiration/sweating/ urinating/excretion
d. Plants absorb water/animals drink water body metabolism.
(iii) x  -   Condensationy  -   Evaporationz  -   Evaporation

(i) a. Temperature/Heat warmth
